Dear Aprille LYNN Sutton:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Special evaluation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327
Section (2) An agency shall inform foster parents of all the following before
Description they are questioned or interviewed regarding a special evaluation:
(b) A clear description of the allegations.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation The agency brought the foster parent to the office to address a
complaint under false pretenses and the foster parent was not
prepared with a support person as entitled.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Child Welfare Director was interviewed by phone 12/20/2024.
She reported the agency received an allegation on 12/5/2024 that
Foster Parent was in a relationship with a person who abuses
drugs and is physically abusive. Also Foster Parent was using
methamphetamine and cocaine. Licensing Worker was assigned
to investigate the allegations and reached out to Foster Parent on
12/9/2024 to inform her of the special evaluation. Licensing
Worker offered to come to Foster Parent to conduct the
investigation. At that time, Licensing Worker told Foster Parent the
allegation was Foster Parent was in a relationship with an abusive
person as Licensing Worker did not want to give Foster Parent A a
“head’s up” about the drug abuse allegation because they did not
want to give Foster Parent time to get drugs out of her system if
she was using them. Child Welfare Director stated the agency
staff’s experience with Foster Parent did not give them any reason
to believe the allegations were true; however, the allegation was
so specific by naming methamphetamine and cocaine as the
drugs being abused and the agency staff could not place children
with her until the allegations were found to be untrue, so they were
trying to complete the evaluation quickly. Child Welfare Director
reported Foster Parent came to the agency the same day at which
time Licensing Worker told Foster Parent about the drug use
allegation and offered Foster Parent a drug test. The drug test
came back positive for marijuana, but not for methamphetamine or
cocaine.
When Child Welfare Director was asked to clarify if Foster Parent
was told of the allegations prior to being interviewed, she stated
Foster Parent was told she was allegedly in a relationship with an
“abusive person which encompasses drug abuse.”
Foster Parent was interviewed by phone 1/7/2025. She stated
she works for a foster care agency and was at a work event on
12/9/2024 when Licensing Worker called her to inform her there
was an allegation Foster Parent was in an abusive relationship.
Licensing Worker informed her she could have a support person
present during her interview. Foster Parent stated she did not
need a support person present as she was not in that relationship,
so she told Licensing Worker she would come to the agency the
following day to be interviewed to expedite the investigation.
When Foster Parent arrived at the agency the following day, she
2

sat down with Licensing Worker who told her the allegation was
that Foster Parent was using drugs and Foster Parent needed to
take a drug test. Foster Parent was surprised and asked Licensing
Worker what would happen if she did not take the drug test to
which Licensing Worker responded it would “look bad,” so Foster
Parent complied. Foster Parent reported she was never told what
licensing rule was being investigated. Foster Parent stated
Licensing Worker never asked her about her personal safety or
anything about being in a physically abusive relationship.
Licensing Worker was interviewed via video conferencing
1/17/2025. Compliance Director was also present during the
interview as a support person. Licensing Worker reported her
supervisor assigned her an investigation regarding allegations that
Foster Parent was in a romantic relationship with a man who is a
known drug abuser and who has been abusive to relationship
partners in the past. The allegation also included Foster Parent
using illegal substances. Licensing Worker stated she was
assigned the special evaluation on a Thursday and reached out to
Foster Parent by phone the following Monday. Licensing Worker
reported she told Foster Parent a complaint came into the agency
with concerns resulting in a special evaluation. She stated Foster
Parent sounded anxious and pressed Licensing Worker for
additional information. Licensing Worker stated she couldn’t tell
Foster Parent about the drug use allegations because she wanted
to drug screen her. Foster Parent pressed further so Licensing
Worker told her the allegations were that she was in a romantic
relationship with a guy who is “inappropriate, unsafe, and
abusive.” Licensing Worker told Foster Parent she needed to get
with her in the next few days after which Foster Parent suggested
they meet at Licensing Worker’s office the following day. Licensing
Worker informed Foster Parent she could have a support person
present. Licensing Worker stated they met the following day in the
agency visit room at which time Licensing Worker explained to
Foster Parent the allegations about being in an abusive
relationship and drug use. When later asked to clarify specifically
what she told Foster Parent the allegations were at this point,
Licensing Worker responded, the person with whom Foster Parent
was in a romantic relationship with was inappropriate, a known
drug abuser, and was abusive in past relationships. Licensing
Worker stated Foster Parent immediately responded stating she
was no longer in that relationship. Foster Parent stated she broke
up with that individual a few weeks prior because his ex-tried to
start a fight with Foster Parent. Licensing Worker stated it was at
that point she told Foster Parent there were also allegations of
Foster Parent using illegal drugs. Foster Parent denied using
3

illegal drugs after which Licensing Worker told Foster Parent, she
believed her and asked her to “voluntarily submit to a drug
screen.” Foster Parent asked Licensing Worker about marijuana,
stating it might be in her system. Licensing Worker told her
marijuana use was ok as long as, if it was in her home, it was
locked up and not being used around kids. Licensing Worker told
her she had the right to not submit to take the drug test, but “it’s
not a good look” if she didn’t.
When asked to clarify if Licensing Worker gave Foster Parent a
detailed description of the full allegations, including drug use by
Foster Parent, before questioning Foster Parent, Licensing
Worker stated she asked Foster Parent if she was romantically
involved with the person in question. Licensing Worker also asked
how long she had been with him and how long it had been since
they broke up. She stated she thought Foster Parent was a nice
lady and was understanding of the special evaluation. Licensing
Worker stated she was being empathetic with Foster Parent and
gave her the vibe the agency was looking out for her.
DOCUMENTATION REVIEWED
• Special Evaluation Report (SER) completed by Licensing
Worker and approved by Licensing Supervisor
documenting the evaluation was opened under foster home
licensing rule 400.9201-1-e. The SER documented no
violation was established as Foster Parent’s drug screen
was negative and she broke things off with the man in
questions after noticing red flags.
Analysis A violation is established as Licensing Worker reported asking
Foster Parent questions about the allegations prior to giving her
the full and detailed description of the allegations.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Special evaluation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327
Section (1) Upon receipt of any information that relates to possible
Description noncompliance with any foster home rule, the agency must do all
the following:
(c) Conduct an evaluation, in cooperation with child protective
services, when applicable, including all necessary collateral
contacts.
4

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Household members were not interviewed during the special
evaluation.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Foster Parent was interviewed by phone 1/7/2025. Foster Parent
stated she received a report indicating she was found in
compliance; however, Licensing Worker has called and texted her
multiple times stating she needed to speak to Foster Parent’s
adult children about Foster Parent’s “drug use.”
Licensing Worker was interviewed via video conferencing
1/17/2025. Compliance Director was also present during the
interview as a support person. Licensing Worker reported after
Foster Parent completed her drug screen Foster Parent “got in her
own head.” Also, Foster Parent works with a person who
previously worked at the agency who was likely giving her advice.
Foster Parent called Licensing Worker and asked her who made
the complaint and when the special evaluation would be closed.
Licensing Worker stated she told Foster Parent she believed
everything Foster Parent told her, but she couldn’t close the
special evaluation until everything was resolved. Foster Parent
called Licensing worker again the day the drug results were
received at which time Licensing Worker told her the test was
negative and that she was trying to hurry to complete the special
evaluation. Licensing Worker stated she tried to hurry and send
the report to Licensing Supervisor who approved the report.
Licensing Supervisor sent Foster Parent the approved report via
USPS along with a determination letter. Licensing Supervisor
realized the following day that Licensing Worker did not interview
Foster Parent’s adult daughters who live with her, so Licensing
Worker called Foster Parent. Foster Parent didn’t answer, so
Licensing Worker sent a text to Foster Parent, but Foster Parent
didn’t respond, so Licensing Worker called her again the following
day at which time she left a voicemail that she needed to ask
Foster Parent about the marijuana. Foster Parent didn’t respond,
so Licensing Worker sent a text asking to speak with Foster
Parent’s adult daughters. Licensing Worker stated her supervisor
spoke with the DCWL Central Office Consultant assigned to the
agency who said they needed to write an addendum to the initial
SER and, if Foster Parent did not respond, the agency needs to
open a new Special Evaluation because she is refusing to
participate.
5

Licensing Supervisor was interviewed by phone 12/20/2024.
She reported she approved Licensing Worker’s report in which
Foster Parent was found in compliance despite Licensing Worker
not having interviewed all of the adult household members.
Licensing Supervisor stated Licensing Worker has to now
interview the two adult household members living with Foster
Parent. Licensing Supervisor was advised to reach out to the
agency’s assigned central office consultant to determine how to
move forward.
DOCUMENTATION REVIEWED
• Special Evaluation Report completed by Licensing Worker
and approved by Licensing Supervisor documenting the
only interview completed regarding the allegation was with
Foster Parent.
Analysis A violation is established as no interviews were conducted with
any members of the foster home, the complainant, or any other
individuals other than Foster Parent.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Special evaluation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327
Section • (4) Before completion of the written report required by
Description subrule (6) of this rule, an agency shall provide the foster
parent with a verbal summary of the preliminary findings at
the conclusion of the evaluation.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Verbal Summary of preliminary findings is documented within the
SER to have not been provided.
Investigation DOCUMENTATION REVIEWED
• Special Evaluation Report completed by Licensing Worker
and approved by Licensing Supervisor documenting a
verbal summary or preliminary findings was not provided.
Analysis A violation is established as it is documented in the special
evaluation report a verbal summary of preliminary findings was not
provided at the conclusion of the evaluation and prior to the
written report.
Conclusion Violation Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
